reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: I stay in businesses I understand. While cars are simple, Tesla’s heavy reliance on cutting-edge software, battery chemistry, and autonomous driving puts it outside my comfort zone. 2. Competitive Moat: Tesla has a powerful brand and early lead in EVs, but as legacy automakers and new entrants pour in capital, that edge may erode. Its supercharger network and software are valuable, yet not impenetrable. 3. Management Quality: Elon Musk is visionary, but his erratic behavior and governance concerns don’t match the steady, shareholder-oriented management teams I admire—think Coke’s Muhtar Kent or Apple’s Tim Cook. 4. Financial Health: Tesla has shown profits and cash flow, but requires relentless, high capital spending and operates in a cyclical industry with commodity-like margins. 5. Valuation & Margin of Safety: At current sky-high multiples, there’s no margin of safety—I’d be paying a king’s ransom for future hopes, not proven, sustainable earnings. 6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: EV adoption will grow, yet mounting competition, shrinking regulatory credits, supply chain swings, and margin pressure pose real risks. 7. Portfolio Comparison: I’d rather own wonderful businesses like Coca-Cola or Apple, which offer durable pricing power, fortress balance sheets, and top-notch capital allocation, at fair prices. When I can’t clearly assess value or see a durable moat, I say “no.” So, I’m passing on TSLA.
